Patch Set 19: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully merged
Hi Matt, thanks for the change. I've left some initial thoughts inline; I'll hold off on further review for now as I expect things might get re-arranged a bit in response.

I prefer it isn't possible for this to be application-defined. This seems like an easy way to get an ABI mismatch that ends in memory safety issues.

If it needs to be adaptable, encoding the value in the build configuration and shipping the fixed constant in the installed header without an `#ifndef`-guard might be an acceptable middle-ground?
Done
We should probably have a `static_assert()` that `PLDM_FIRMWARE_MAX_STRING <= UINT8_MAX`?
Done

My current maintenance stance is that all new APIs should use negative error-codes, even if this is inconsistent with existing stable APIs in the same "family". The conflation of PLDM CCs with implementation errors isn't something I'd like to continue with, and I intend to migrate existing stable APIs to use negative error codes over time.

Can you please fix this throughout?
Done

So while `LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL` is exposed in the installed headers, its intended use is only for `static inline` functions for iterator implementations via the `LIBPLDM_ITERATOR` annotation. Function symbols exposed by the library should do proper error handling of NULL arguments if they require non-NULL values (and annotating them with `LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL` causes a compiler warning/error for that required error-handling).
Done

My current preference for the design of libpldm APIs is that we add a regular struct (not packed) that captures the message members, and pass a (const) pointer through the encode functions. I feel this keeps things coherent with respect to the message definitions, requires fewer parameters for the function definition, and in the case of `decode_*()` functions removes the burden on tests for pointer validity (as we only need to test the struct pointer). As a bit of a hand-wave, it also helps address ambiguity about whether an object passed by reference points to an array or just a single object in the API definition.

The preference impacts the remainder of the API definitions here, so once we have consensus on an approach we'll need to adjust the rest as necessary too.

Also, can we pass through a pointer to an array of `struct pldm_descriptor` for `descriptor_data` rather than `const uint8_t *` (which I expect would be better as `const void *` otherwise)? Trying to keep the APIs defined in terms of concrete types rather than pointers to opaque buffers helps mentally model the relationships between things and so improves ergonomics.
I've changed it to use `struct pldm_descriptor`, and also changed `encode_get_status_resp` to take a struct argument rather than several separate arguments.

Rather than `struct variable_field` here, can we use the structs you're defining above? I'd like to avoid direct references to `struct variable_field` in the public APIs where possible, because it's such a vague type.
Done
Same query regarding `struct variable_field` as above.
Done
The comment on line 932 covers this. I prefer we define a struct type that captures these, and pass a pointer to the struct instance instead.
Done

Can we please avoid adding further invocations of `reinterpret_cast<>()`? `PLDM_MSG_DEFINE_P()` can be used here instead.

This applies to other instances throughout the change as well.
Done
Open to better naming suggestions than `_full` for these structs.

Let's go with `_full` for now. But, I think eventually we want to get rid of the wire-format structs from the header. Given that, it would be nice if down the track we can rename the structs to drop `_full`. In order to get there we could also now add a typedef for the `_full` structs and document that consumers should use the typedef rather than a raw `struct ..._full`. Then down the track when we've removed the wire-format structs we can drop the `_full` from the struct name and deprecate the typedef for removal.

Thoughts?

Perhaps if the typedef doesn't have the `_full` suffix but maps to the `_full` struct it will be easier to "remove" down the track after we've renamed the struct, as it will be a matter of adding `struct ` in-front of the typedef name where it's used.

Having both `struct pldm_component_parameter_entry` and `pldm_component_parameter_entry` (typedef to the a different `_full` struct) seems error prone (if I'm understanding correctly).

The functions taking the old wire structs will also need migration (`decode_get_firmware_parameters_resp` for example), not sure if those will need new names too?

> Having both struct pldm_component_parameter_entry and pldm_component_parameter_entry (typedef to the a different _full struct) seems error prone (if I'm understanding correctly).

Yeah, that's a fair concern (especially wrt C++).

> The functions taking the old wire structs will also need migration (decode_get_firmware_parameters_resp for example), not sure if those will need new names too?

Yep. We can make that Future Andrew's problem for now.
Acknowledged
This doesn't match the parameters?
Done
Was there a trade-off consideration with not struct-ifying these? I have the same query on the APIs added below as well.
It didn't seem worth creating a struct to pass just a couple of arguments. Can add structs to all of them if you'd prefer.

Yeah, I'm still trying to find the balance and so I appreciate your input here. My existing recommendation was for the encode/decode APIs is to use a struct regardless.

I think the concerning circumstances here are:

1. The number of message parameters is low (2)
2. None of the parameters require pointers and so there's no need for object size arguments
3. We're encoding a message - decoding is where we're most exposed to the potential to overflow short out-buffers.

So then it comes back to consistency.

Regarding 3, having different design rules for encode and decode APIs feels awkward, and I don't feel like I want to compromise on the decode side (all out parameters must be pointers), which leaves me preferring that encode APIs have struct arguments.

Regarding 1 I feel that we'd at least have to find some line in the sand for how many parameters are too many (look at function call ABIs for various ISAs?).

I appreciate that when taken as a whole the current libpldm APIs generally aren't consistent, or where they are they're consistent in ways I have a preference against (instance ID parameter to encode APIs, PLDM completion codes for error handling, etc), but the aim is to repair all that.

How much do you think compound literals (... at least, for C) salvage the "always a struct" approach?

```
encode_request_update_resp(iid, &(struct pldm_request_update_resp){ len, flag }, msg, plen);
```

I'll change them to all passed structs. Not sure that compound literals are much more legible than a struct instance on the lines above, but maybe that's just unfamiliar to my eyes.

I don't think function call ABI should matter too much - if size/performance is an issue then applying LTO would make that all moot.

> I'll change them to all passed structs.

Okay.

> Not sure that compound literals are much more legible than a struct instance on the lines above, but maybe that's just unfamiliar to my eyes.

Yeah, it's only saving naming the thing. It'd be nice if `&(auto){ ... }` worked...

> I don't think function call ABI should matter too much - if size/performance is an issue then applying LTO would make that all moot.

Yeah, I was just considering leveraging ABIs to define a line in the sand for "how many arguments are too many", not really anything more than that.
Done
This seems to be a recurring pattern below. Perhaps we should add an API for it? `pldm_msgbuf_destroy_size()` or something?

Maybe `pldm_msgbuf_used(msgbuf*, size_t orig_len, size_t *ret_used_len)` ?
In this case it'd be called as `pldm_msgbuf_used(buf, *payload_len, payload_len)`.
Sounds good, though how do you feel about `pldm_msgbuf_destroy_used(...)`? Just to make it clear where in the lifecycle it's intended to be invoked.
Fine by me.
Done

Hi Matt, I have some comments on the implementation now. Largely looks good.

I have some longer-term thoughts brewing on the APIs themselves, but as they're marked testing we can get what you've written submitted without worrying about that too much.
Is there a reason this is necessary?
Don't think so, removed.
Done
Is there a reason this can't be `pldm_msgbuf_destroy_consumed()`?
Thanks, hadn't seen that function
Same as discussed above.
Done
Makes sense
As discussed above.
Done
See discussions above.
Done
